newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft CFO says estimates high enough.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft CFO says estimates high enough.

text.p: Microsoft Chief Financial Officer Mike Brown said Thursday analysts should "resist any temptation" to raise their estimates for the company's earnings for the fiscal year that began July 1.
Analysts on average expect Microsoft to earn $3.15 a share, according to First Call, compared with $2.63 for the year just ended.
In a conference call with analysts, Brown gave a laundry list of reasons to be cautious, including expected slower growth in personal computer sales. But he said he was bullish for the long term.
In the conference call, the company treasurer, Greg Maffei, said Microsoft did not buy back any stock in the latest quarter because "we thought the price was a little high."
The company had repurchased $3 billion in stock earlier in the fiscal year and plans to continue the buyback program, he said.

Microsoft executives said its high-end Windows NT operating system continues to gain market share. Windows NT now has an estimated 40 percent of the market in Intel Corp servers, up from from 25 percent a year earlier, they said during the call.
Maffei, who succeeds Brown as CFO this month, said Windows NT Workstation sales nearly tripled in the year.
Windows NT accounted for about 10 percent of last year's $3.48 billion in revenues from computer manufacturers, or OEMs, he said, and that percentage is expected to grow.
Maffei said Windows NT Workstation sales were 29 percent of Windows 95 revenues and 14 percent of Windows 95 units in the latest quarter.
Brown predicted overall pressure on profit margins in the current fiscal year would hold the earnings growth rate close to the company's revenue growth rate.
He said he expected the company's cost of goods sold would be about 9 percent of revenues in the current year, compared with 9.6 percent in the year just ended and 7.6 percent in the latest quarter.

Brown also said the company probably would take a charge against earnings of $0.25 a share in the current quarter and $0.01-$0.02 in the second quarter assuming it completes its planned $425 million acquisition of WebTV Networks Inc.
